interlinear-text.item: GSK ʂəʝd xun çak - sɨj ʂkor [3]

phrase.item: House Construction
First we choose a spot and we bring over stones.
Once the stones have been brought over, we lay down the foundation.
Once the foundation is finished, we prepare the wheat 'batt'.
Once the foundation has been laid we construct the walls.
Next we gather logs.
We call in an artisan to square them off.
Once the logs are squared we set down the main beam on a specific day and to celebrate this we sacrifice a lamb.
When the main beam is set, we position the other beams of the roof.
After the roof beams we add the transverse rafters connected to the frame.
Once the transverse rafters are placed, we raise the walls.
Once the walls are raised, we place covering longitudinal laths over the transverse rafters.
Over the longitudinal covering we arrange reeds.
We put gravel on top of the reeds.
Over the gravel, we spread soil.
When all of this is done, we build nares (raised areas of soil built along the walls inside a house) and we put up the partitions.
Next we light a fire in the house, we organize a great celebration, [and] we move into and live in this house.
Hunting
In the evening I think to myself: "I will go hunting."
I order that we bake bread,
I take it and put it in the fold of my dress.
I fasten my belt and set off.
‎‎I wake up and leave at six in the morning.
When the sun rises, I reach the hunting area.
There, I'm on the lookout for a mouflon (bighorn sheep).
Next I determine which side I'm better off shooting from.
Then I begin to get closer to the mouflon.
Once there's about one hundred meters between us, I fire.
If I killed him I'm going to slice his head (cut his head off).
I skin him.
Having skinned him, I throw away its stomach, intestines, [and] head.
I also leave his horns.
I put the two forequarters in the skin and I hide the two hindquarters in a cave and I leave them there after having covered them with a wall.
I cook the heart, liver, lungs and kidneys on the spot.
I place down a flat stone under which I light a fire.
I place them on the stone and on top of them I lay another flat stone that crushes (flattens) them.
When they are cooked I eat a part of them and I bring part of them home.
I pack the meat on my back and I bring it home.
‎‎Next we come back to get the two hindquarters.
If we were three [people], we would divide the quarters in three parts.
The hunter takes the breast (chest) for himself.
A passerby takes the horns. (?)
At home we put this meat in a large cauldron (pot)/
When it is cooked we divide it in bowls and we distribute it in the hamlet (village).
After having eaten the meat, we read the following prayer:
The game escapes,
The hunt repeats
according to the thinking of Choyi mardon.
This we have eaten. Bring us ten more.
Bring no misfortune to the master of this body.
Allah is great.
Hare Hunt
We leave with ten people to go hunting.
We bring a svand, a long stick of about a meter and a half long.
We take dogs.
We look for the hares.
We walk around randomly, here's a scurrying hare, the dogs throw themselves on its [the hare] heels.
When he passes in front of you, you throw the stick on (at) him.
The stick falls on the hare and he too falls.
Either the dogs go get it or you get it yourself.
Then you cut its head off and here (in the village) you skin it.
We cook it in the hearth (oven).
There are people who kill three or four hares,
There are some who don't kill any, who take nothing, but we give them some out of fraternity.
